comments.commentBody: I can't argue with what you and Kay say here - seems absolutely right to me. But it may be that the country is edging toward the California model, where to be a viable GOP candidate for statewide office one has to be a Celebrity (or the office obscure).

Correction:  ensus figures show that US population increased by 36% during the period 1980-2010, about TWICE the rate of growth of production of doctors in American medical schools. That is why medical costs are soaring.

Brett's refusal to consider data, facts is really getting my goat. I have pointed out innumerable times that there are countries with a lower density of physicians that get better health care results at much lower costs. I have pointed to data that show that in the US the best paid doctors, the most expensive health care, the longest waits are all in those areas with the highest density of physicians. The organization that provides much of the data has written, "Increasing the number of physicians will make our health care system worse, not better." http://www.dartmouthatlas.org/keyissues/issue.aspx?con=2940.

Come on Brett, confront reality.

Your simplistic ideas of supply and demand with regards to medicine are naive at best. It is far more complicated. Try reading about the history of medicine in the US before spouting this nonsense in perpetuity. I suggest "The Social Transformation of American Medicine" by Paul Starr.

Although Trump is crude in his choice of words, he did raise an issue that is important and that no other Republican candidate has had the courage to address forcefully.

The US needs to decide at what level illegal immigration should be permitted. The default option is NO illegal immigration, because that is what is consistent with current law.

Unfortunately, the Hispanic lobby and liberal media tried to shut off debate before the issues were even discussed by calling Trump a "racist" and by attempting reprisals limiting his sources of income, by denying Trump's Miss Universe Contest access to Univision and NBC.

This is inconsistent with the freedom of speech that should be permitted to ALL candidates for public office.

Actually the problem of illegal immigration has NOTHING to do with race. The problem is one of too much population growth for the finite resources of the US. Illegal immigrants take scarce resources from citizens who are lawfully in the country, many of whom have actually APPLIED FOR CITIZENSHIP via the legal process.

Census figures show that US population increased by 36% during the period 1980-2010, about the number of new doctors produced in American medical schools. That is why medical costs are soaring.

That is also one reason that Obama was not able to afford a genuine universal health care system that covers all US citizens.

The result is that people in the US DIE because of inadequate access to cancer screenings, for example.

I can't speak for PK , but my reading.of German publications has caught references to "our" economists as opposed to "Anglo-Saxon" economists in what is intended to refer to economist who follow Keynes.

In their world Asians, Africans etc are all considered "Anglo-Saxon"

Which makes it even stranger that the UK IS following a nonsensical economic policy.

Dr. K,

I agree with the the positon of bearded Princeton economists. I am not sure about Anglo-Saxon. Everyone knows that the tribes of Angles & Saxons, who populated the region now known as Germany, migrated to England and essential dominated/conquered the Scots, Picts and Celts.

However, Mr. Bernanke has the experience & know-how to head up a commission to review the ECB and the rules set forth in its charter to make recommendations to this "central bank" to make it a lot more effective than it is. The EU is not doing well as everyone thought it would & it would be very helpful if this organization reinvented itself, starting with its Central Bank. The G-20 should form the Commission and provide it with the funds & the leadership of Mr. Bernanke. This would be his best and highest use & he might even be able to save GIIPR before a collapse of the EU idea, which was one of the best of modern times. I am ambitious, I abhor arms sales as the principal means for economic growth, but I feel strongly that Russia should be invited to join the EU common market and currency system. At a minimum this should be on the agenda for discussion. The Russian market could kick our Earth home up to a new economic level. I have a terrific continental passenger and freight surface transport system to network the region into a great new, highly networked, market. This would increase the GDP of the region to 4% a year and would put a lot of people back to work.

"Their culture of entitlement, corruption, and cronyism"

Incredible that you're qualified to make such a sweeping statement about an entire nation. Are you intimately familiar with a broad cross-section of lazy and selfish Greek people? Or are you assembling a narrative to fit some morality play about the consequences of borrowing?

C. calling the kettle black? You chastised the whole German nation in your posts. Fred Swartz was absolutely on target with his comments.
Have you ever lived outside of the US? Have you ever lived in a southern European country? I have in several and Swartz is correct.
The austerity approach is like putting debtors in jail.  It punishes them but you can't get payments on the debt from someone in jail.

Greece insists that everyone keep supporting them despite not being willing to change. Their culture of entitlement, corruption, and cronyism has created a failed economy that doesn't belong in the Eurozone. They've taken a lot of money from the troika and don't have anything to show for it because they've made little effort to change. Greece is their own enemy.

Creating an external enemy is a favorite technique of demagogues. Germany, despite being the country which has contributed the most money to Greece, has unjustifiably been turned into an easy target. First, their very dark past can always be used against them. Second, their willingness to speak the unpleasant truth about the situation is necessarily very unflattering to the egocentric Greeks. Very unfair to the Germans.

Greece leaving the Euro, despite that pain, would surely be better than the years of pain and conflict from this latest "agreement".

What rumors? What conspiracy theories? This is what greek officials actually said. You can read it anywhere.

Btw, it's 2015 and I think no sensible person on earth can imagine Germany to bomb other countries now. Though, I can very well imagine the USA doing so.

A heartfelt Semper Fi from this very old Marine to all Marines out there today, that are also suffering the loss of our own. And especially to the families of the Marines that were so callously murdered in cold blood, without even a chance to defend themselves!

Semper Fi 68- 74 RVN 69-71
And your views are....??
Pretty sure he is running as a Republican.
I will vote for Mr Trump over any Democratic candidate.  He represents my views and he speaks them without apology and he does not backtrack when the media mocks him.
My post is accurate.  Yours is not; "controlled" is where you are wrong.

uh, actually the taxpayers made money off that little investment in GM.

just sayin'
mj - actually, no.

The people should not forget that Trump may have found wealth and success, but he has successfully declared bankruptcy several times leaving people like the ones who idolize him "unpaid"!
Donald Trump has filed for corporate bankruptcy four times, in 1991, 1992, 2004 and 2009.
I wish Bernie was better organized, because I don't trust Hillary.  Bernie has some good ideas and he seems authentic; but he will need more than a few miracles to beat the Clinton machine.
Stop wishing and start helping.  If you are really sincere with your feelings, it's time to put up or.....

Bernie has one of the same problems as Trump. He's completely unqualified to run the country. As a candidate you can blowviate all you like. The problem is, once President it becomes much more difficult to accomplish.

You like what he says so you delude yourself into thinking he can move a dug in Congress and a Lobbyist stacked government. It ain't so.

Bernie needs to stay in Congress. He's on our side and we can't afford to lose him from a place where he can actually do some good.

There is one other person who speaks their mind freely in this campaign, and is the very character of disruption to the current status quo: His name is Bernie Sanders, but we don't talk about him here on mainstream media.

First things first: Donald Trump has filed for corporate bankruptcy four times, in 1991, 1992, 2004 and 2009. So i guess he is not that smart a business man. Second; The Donald earned his money the old fashioned way, he inherited all of it.  The guy just is in it for media attention, sorry but he is a joke.  BTW, the country has the lowest unemployment rate since 2008. Osama  B.L. is in the ground. yep, what a mess we are in.
Bernie Sanders called, 10,000 people showed up. And he didn't even have to pay them.
It is strange that a man who has filed for bankruptcy four times believes himself eligible for running this country into anything but the ground.

" they believed the president was a Muslim and was not born in the United States."

I recently came across someone who actually believed that Obama is a Muslim. I confess that previously I had thought that this was just more liberal nonsense to say that such people existed. But this person was real.

I tried to explain to her that Obama is a Christian and this is quite clear if you read the transcript of his speech in Charleston. But I am not sure I was heard.

At the same time, I do not particularly despise people who think Obama is a Muslim and not a US citizen.

Obama was born in Hawaii and not in the mainland US. And moreover, both his stepfather and his paternal grandfather were Muslims. He did spend much of his childhood in Indonesia. Possibly he was registered in the local school as a Muslim.

So the belief that Obama is Muslim is false, and needs to be corrected, but people who think he is Muslim are not entirely crazy. A bit irrational, but they do have a basis for their false beliefs. Why fight with them? Just tell them politely that they are mistaken.
Classic cliché.  If it ain't comin' from the pulpit of my righteous party, then it's all about fear.  And you have the right to vote.  Happy thought.

Great review on what goes on in the minds of the court and behind the scenes.
i agree with you 100%. It has got to begin somewhere and that only occurs when somebody is willing to bring it into the open. Mr. Obama has at least made a first step.
3 strikes is one of the worst put together laws that could have occurred and that alone would change what type of criminals get these long sentences, or any sentences.

There isn't a lot Congress can do. They should (but surely won't) revoke laws imposing mandatory minimum sentences and "three strikes" laws. The federal guidelines were widely copied, with enhancements, by the states. I don't think it's going to do any good until we can find some way to change prosecutors' incentives. Right now prosecutors see convicting people as "winning," not as administering justice. They don't care about "justice," they care about "winning." Prosecutors have complete discretion, and since 1980 they've used that discretion to prosecute more often, charging more serious crimes, piling charges on, demanding guilty pleas, and demanding longer sentences. The people who vote for them don't even know, they just know that this prosecutor is putting a lot of people in jail so they must be criminals who should be in jail so let's vote for him he must be good. Prosecutors don't get credit for making good judgements.

I totally agree with you, he should experience the trash and food thrown out of the cells after being on lock down for a couple of days....in fact, he should have visited a state prison, federal prisons are too nice.....

"... nor launder hundreds of thousands of dollars for a Mexican cartel, ..." Wait a minute, that's what banks do. HSBC. Royal Bank of Scotland. Citigroup. People who do that don't go to jail. The shareholders of their companies pay the fines that are imposed and they get large bonuses because the profits are much more than the fines. That's not a crime, it's just against the law. Try to keep up.

You need to watch the film, "Reefer Madness." It is well known that every person who smokes a joint is certain to become a dope fiend who will steal, rape, and murder, so we must lock them away at the first sign the have used weed. Preferably forever. Broken windows. There are no offenses which do not hurt other people. If they resist arrest they are inciting revolution and must be locked up to protect society. /snark

You describe these things as costs, but they are not. These are the goals, the purposes, of the policies that produce them. The purpose of mass incarceration is to control the low status populace.  If "those people" are not prevented from voting they will vote Democrat, so convict them of felonies and they cannot vote Democratic. Also, capitalism needs a large reserve army of unemployed on the verge of starvation.

All of which might, but does not necessarily, imply the intercession of divine providence.  I think the president is only stating metaphorically that It could have been him had he not had the mitigating influences that made all the difference.   I don't interpret his metaphoric statement as being religious, but only an acknowledgement of fortuitous circumstances that allowed him to mature past the angry, disaffected, testosterone-driven stage that many (if not most) adolescent boys and young men go through.

While their mistakes may not have ruined the USA, have you looked at the costs to jail an inmate? The average annual cost in 2010 was $31 286/inmate. That's what's ruining the USA. I fully agree murderers, rapists, violent criminals, etc should be jailed, but someone for selling a bag of marijuana? And at that cost to the tax payer? Give me a break..
That's not true. I've read accounts that people from Europe and the Middle East come to the US and learn they're black, for instance.

One thing is still missing from US discussions of racism. Americans, both black and white, talk as if racism is strictly an American phenomenon. It is universal, it is part of every human's psyche. I think it is not possible to deal with our racism, as individuals, without confronting this fact.

I read Between the World and Me in its entirety today. Thoroughly captivating, Coates allows readers (namely his son) to witness how his identity as a black man while inherently vulnerable, is also empowered by the life-events highlighted throughout the book.

Coates shares his growth and search for "the right question" from the hardened streets of Baltimore to the intellectual Mecca at Howard University, to the insecurities of parenthood, to self awareness as a black man outside the United States in Paris. He's also honest about his potential limitations as a God-less man while other blacks in his midst pray for their oppressors.

Between the World and Me shouldn't be read because he's the next James Baldwin of the black community, it should be read because Ta-Nehisi Coates is a profoundly relevant voice within 21st century American culture - poised, combative, fearful, loving, inquisitive, empathetic...imperfectly human.

As a biracial woman who consciously navigates her whiteness and blackness on a daily basis both here in Canada and when traveling back to Los Angeles, I could identify with Coates, yet also pinched by his stance on whiteness and what he calls the "Dream". Yes! Thank you. My wheels are still turning...

Of course now I'd love to hear how his son (and my daughter's) generation responds to the book. He writes from his experiences; our younger generations should be preparing to do the same.

True you statistics might be, but still irrelevant to Mr. Coates' book.

Mr. Coates talks about all the violence that Black Americans have to live with. He's not pointing fingers - which you'd realize if you read the book.

Black Americans, regardless of their wishes, are compelled by racism and segregation, institutional and otherwise, to live in more violent environments than most White Americans. That is also a true statistic, and the one which Mr. Coates addresses.
And your point is?

Spoken like a true Dylann Roof, and as true Southerner, with the very recent Sandra Bland case,  William Case. By pointing this out you are denying that racism exists and that the underlying cause of crime is centuries of racism and discrimination. Let me illustrate for you: Slavery (246 years), sharecropping and more importantly relentless terrorism of freed blacks (1865-Now/150 years), disenfranchisement, redlining or banks refusing to lend in mostly black areas (Then people like you wonder why there are ghettos?), poor education due to underfunded communities, deliberate distribution of drugs in black neighborhoods since the 1930's (crack, etc), the school to prison pipeline, the prison industrial complex, ongoing job discrimination (I just experienced it in an interview despite a good education, years of experience and a portfolio.) You wouldn't last a week being black in America. And you know this because you don't have to think about it. You can just sit back and point fingers.

According to a recent New York Times article, “In police homicides in which the victim’s race is identified, African-Americans account for about three in 10 deaths, and whites roughly half. “ So blacks are the victims in about 30 percent of police homicides while non-Hispanics whites are the victims in about 50 percent. The article points out that this means “blacks are three times as likely to be killed by cops as are whites" but adds that blacks are “five times as likely to feloniously kill a cop.”The truth is that racial disparity in police homicides is much smaller than the racial disparity in violent crime.

Interracial murders are relatively rare, but blacks are considerably faster than whites on the interracial trigger finger. The FBI Uniform Crime Report 2013 (Expanded Homicide Data Table 6) shows that 409 blacks murdered whites while 189 whites (including Hispanics) murdered blacks in 2013, the most recent year for which data is complete. Table 6 also shows 13.6 percent of white homicide victims were killed by black offenders and 7.6 percent of black homicide victims were killed by white offenders, including Hispanics.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/01/us/no-sharp-rise-seen-in-police-killin...

To your question: who is it written for? Coates wrote it for his son. But in publishing it, he is sharing with a wider public, especially members of his racial group. As an Asian American, I understand this perspective and don't view it as "purely binary" -- black or white." Many people of color can understand what it is to have their bodies appropriated and damaged through racial stereotyping. During wartime, this might even result in government policies that incarcerate tens of thousands of bodies without trial -- as occurred during World War II when 120,000 people of Japanese descent were put behind barbed wire in remote imprisonment camps.

But if others who might not have shared my experience of being asked, "what are you?" or "do your people tan?" or "can you see when you smile?" then it would be great if those people were interested. But it wasn’t written for them (nor to exclude).

If a woman who wrote a similar "letter" to her daughter about sexism and male privilege, would people get so excited if she launched her book in a woman's bookstore?  Would they say, "oh she's excluding men?"  I think we would understand the context.  A member of a group that has been long oppressed might want to share first with her community, the primary readers.  But I feel that Coates would welcome compassionate witnesses from any race, religion, gender.

Most authors have some intended audience in mind when they write a book or at least a sense of who might most appreciate their voice as it gives life to the content. What I take is that Mr. Coates wrote the book first and foremost for people who have experienced or more naturally understand his journey and point-of-view, neither of which are necessarily true for me as a white male early GenXer/late Boomer.  But I am enjoying the book and receiving a great deal of ideas worth contemplating.  We don't get to appropriate his writing talent for the book we would prefer he writes; we can only opt to read the one he has written.

That applies to Coates as well. He will never understand what it is to be white, and he imagines that everything comes easily to to the white people. If things are hard for the black people, it must be because of "racism".

“It was very, very important, as far as I was concerned, that the book be launched in an African-American space,” Mr. Coates, 39, said in an interview the morning after the event. “I wanted to be very clear about who the book was written for, how it was written, what it came out of.”

I am confused. Is it written for African-Americans, or is it written for the wider American audience? If the book is launched in an "African-American space", isn't it like self-segregating? As someone who is neither white nor black, and who wants to understand and learn and grow, I am not sure what message Coates has for someone like me. On one hand, his purely binary white-black view leaves out a significant portion of the current American population. At the same time, there is a certain accusatory tone, that I find alienating. Almost like being told, "if you are not black, at best you don't count; at worst you are part of the white power structure." I submit there is another way - a way that includes all people of good will regardless of their color. Coates' book is not it.
